title: Keeping the lights and Netlfix on getting easier
text:
"Our forecast comes from an expectation that the CPI data will start to include dwelling rental depreciation, falls in electricity charges from new retail pricing regulations, lower retail petrol from lower global oil prices and declines in vegetable and clothing prices and deposit and loan facilities," Citi economist Josh Williamson said.

ANZ's daily tracking of petrol prices indicates a fall of around 2 per cent for the quarter.

But it's the energy space where economists expect some noteable movements.

NAB economist Kaixin Owyong said the new “default market offers” in NSW, Victoria, Queensland and South Australia were likely to result in a significant reduction in prices.

"There is a sizable degree of uncertainty about the extent that the default market offer reduced energy prices, it’s possible the effect is greater than the 2 per cent fall we have estimated," Ms Owyong said.

"We see downside risk here."

Furthermore, she sees a slip in childcare costs of 1 per cent in the quarter.

"Changes to childcare subsidy took place on July 1, increasing the subsidy available to an estimated 1 million families.

Advertisement

"When the childcare subsidy was first created in the third quarter of 2018 child care costs fell 12 per cent in that quarter. Again there could be downside risk here."

Discretionary items are set to be the main contributors to the inflation figure, with a rise in both domestic and international travel set to contribute 0.3 percentage points in the quarter according to Westpac.

ANZ's Hayden Dimes expects the drought could have some inflationary effect on food.

"We expect fruit and vegetable prices to add to inflation, increasing 1.5 per cent," Mr Dimes said. "Wholesale prices suggest fruit prices are up sharply, more than offsetting the fall in vegetable prices. With the ongoing drought, there is some upside risk to food inflation."

Tobacco and alcohol prices also expected to have risen during the quarter and Commonwealth Bank is expecting them to contribute 0.11 percentage points to Wednesday's print.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia economist Gareth Aird expects the September quarter to become the 15th consecutive quarter of below-target core inflation - the Reserve Bank's preferred measure - which he said will at least help those households experiencing low wage growth.

"For workers, modest wages growth is outpacing inflation so real wages are in positive territory," Mr Aird said.
description: Price falls in some of the biggest household budget items are expected to restrain headline inflation.
